Develop or revise the mechanism and structure to receive and rapidly distribute funds during emergencies. Conduct a simulation exercise or after-action review to assess functionality of the new finance policy or procedures. Document outcomes and make necessary changes to optimize procedure.
Demonstrate and document that the funds are mobilized in advance of a public health emergency.
Develop accounting and reporting procedures for accountability and transparency of all emergency SOP and MOU’s that will be used during emergency response.
Conduct training for NFPs.
Regularly test the mechanism for multisectoral collaboration and communication through actual experience and/or scenarios for high risk, deliberate or mass gathering events.
Routinely conduct after-action reviews or simulations and apply the lessons learnt relating to coordination and NFP role, prioritized for actions within national action plans.
Document and disseminate evidence that the coordination mechanism is working to address zoonoses and other existing or new health events at the human–animal interface.
Document and share best practices.
Identify a health ministry lead for AMR, develop a clear terms of reference and coordinate activities of the relevant ministries on AMR and stewardship.
Organize effective coordination through regular meetings.
Identify and map sustained funding for planned activities in the AMR national action plan.
Define clearly specified actions within planning and governance mechanisms for all key sectors involved.
Demonstrate continuous improvement of data quality at all levels, using assessment results.

Designate a national reference laboratory to support AMR surveillance and develop SOPs for verification and additional testing and identify an external quality assessment provider for the national reference laboratory.
Define national AMR surveillance objectives and develop a national AMR surveillance strategy.
Expand AMR testing and surveillance to include other clinical sites and/or other areas of the healthcare system (such as private sector).
Establish a National IPC Committee and develop National IPC Committee terms of reference and local IPC committees at district and/or facility level, if an action plan is not in place.

Implement the action plan, informed by assessment results and following the five-step cycle described in the practical manuals, according to the WHO requirements/action checklists for the priority core components identified.
Include specific interventions for AMR prevention tailored to the local epidemiological situation in these plans.
Analyse and regularly report national IPC and WASH data and support discussions on actions to incorporate lessons learned in the long-term improvement plan.
Develop a draft national antimicrobial stewardship plan or strategy and national legislation that regulate use, availability and quality of antimicrobials.
Implement antimicrobial stewardship programmes, including monitoring of antimicrobial use, education/communication, and other interventions to improve antibiotic use, at designated facilities.
Expand antimicrobial stewardship activities to all healthcare facilities.
Monitor antibiotic quality and address drivers of prescribing behaviours.
Develop strategy, guidelines and SOPs for coordinated surveillance and reporting of at least two priority zoonotic diseases of greatest national public health concern.
Train responsible staff for specific aspects of the surveillance and management of priority zoonotic diseases at national and subnational levels.
Use coordinated surveillance data to inform disease prevention and control efforts across all relevant sectors.
Based on the results of these exercises or reviews, update the guidelines, SOPs and operational plan where appropriate.
Develop and disseminate training packages on these guidelines and SOPs.
Ensure that access to laboratory capacity to detect pathogens for any priority zoonoses is included in the response plans.
Monitor and evaluate the multisectoral coordination mechanism for cresponse regularly.
Develop a strategy to monitor trends and detect foodborne events to incorporate within the national communicable disease surveillance strategy (see surveillance technical area).

Ensure provision of resources for the investigation of foodborne disease or food contamination events at the national level. This should include investigations into hazards in foods linked to cases, outbreaks or events.
Train identified foodborne disease surveillance and food contamination monitoring focal points in the surveillance of such hazards.
Designate an INFOSAN Emergency Contact Point in the government agency responsible for the response and management of food safety emergencies.
Develop and disseminate training packages on SOPs and guidelines for the response and management of food safety emergencies.
Establish a mechanism of sharing information regularly by the INFOSAN Emergency Contact Point with the IHR NFP, INFOSAN Focal Points and all relevant sectors during a food safety emergency.
Review and update the management and response plan based on these findings.
Integrate the WHO Global Vaccine Action Plan eradication and elimination goals into the national immunization plan.
Disseminate messaging tools to improve knowledge-based capacities (communication and education) of healthcare staff for community socialization.
Implement a routine monitoring and evaluation system for health workers who perform immunization.
Conduct formal surveys of hard-to-reach areas to ensure that coverage rates among vulnerable populations are >90%.
Identify barriers to procuring, receiving, storing and deploying vaccines to targeted populations.
Establish a cold chain for vaccine delivery to at least 40–59% of districts or 40–59% of the target population.
Conduct quality assurance of cold chain equipment and delivery systems.
Routinely analyse the inventory system to monitor vaccine supply needs and forecast requirements, with anticipated procurement.
Assess laboratory algorithms, standards and testing capacity including equipment inventory for the 10 priority diseases.
Regularly train staff on the testing, and document quality control results.
Conduct monitoring and evaluation to document diagnostics, data quality and staff performance, and incorporate recommendations into the national laboratory strategic plan.
Train staff of courier company and health facility on appropriate management of specimens from suspected cases of priority diseases.
Provide preposition outbreak investigation kits (sample collection and transportation kits) at 80% or more health facilities.
Establish a system to collect and test specimens from hard-to-reach areas.
Conduct a review of existing point-of-care/rapid diagnostic tests that are available to the country for detection of priority diseases.
Obtain sustainable funding for laboratory procurement, capacity building and point-of care diagnostics.
Develop expertise by training selected laboratory staff in the inspection of laboratories based on the standards.
Conduct assessments of current biosafety and biosecurity practices, procedures and engineering controls at the national level.
Implement biosafety and biosecurity best practices in all national, intermediate and local laboratories.
Develop and implement an incident reporting system that includes identifying incidents, reporting according to regulations, and addressing action items that improve safety and security.
Secure sustainable funding and an oversight and enforcement mechanism to support biosafety and biosecurity programmes/initiatives at the ministry level.
Review training needs assessments on a regular basis and adjust and update training programmes according to the assessment results.
Identify resources for control of priority diseases.

Establish a process to ensure that reported cases or events with outbreak potential are investigated and assessed for public health response and linked to the laboratory results, and that data from the investigation are managed in a standardized timeframe and manner.

Develop a mechanism for cross-border surveillance by means of an agreed cross-border surveillance system at points of entry, or some other mechanism of regularly sharing data and information between neighbouring countries.
Develop a plan and process to support efforts of other countries to develop/enhance surveillance systems, including contributing to regional and/or international surveillance networks.
Develop operational plan, standards for data, and plans for interoperability and data sharing.
Develop and disseminate SOPs, procedures and guidelines at all levels.
Conduct routine training on application or software for surveillance staff at all levels, including 100% of national- and intermediate-level surveillance staff.
Test interoperability of the electronic system with other relevant electronic tools of other sectors.
Produce ad hoc reports of analysed surveillance data for outbreaks or other public health events and disseminate from the national level.
Develop a process and publish routine reports of epidemiological information for priority diseases at the national level.
Produce analyses and disseminate epidemiologic interpretation of all major events at all levels.
Develop a plan to fund and implement the health workforce strategy (animal and human health sector), and donor contributions.
Create appropriate job classification and job description for health workers at all levels of the relevant ministries, and clear career ladder.

Map and align investment in human resources for health with the current and future needs of the population and health systems to address shortages and enhance distribution of health workers, to enable maximum improvements in health outcomes, social welfare, employment creation and economic growth (Global Strategy on HRH 2030 Obj2).
Establish a national (and subnational where relevant) continuing professional education programme for professionals (Global Strategy on HRH 2030 Obj1.24).
Establish or strengthen national rapid response teams so that it is multidisciplinary and multilevel.

Develop continuing professional education programmes, in priority One Health disciplines, at the national and subnational levels within the strategic framework that also tracks workforce retention and performance.
Develop and implement SOPs on how professionals at the national and subnational levels communicate during an infectious disease outbreak.
Identify and document all trainings related to contingency planning, management of emergency situations, risk communications, and joint exercises for multidisciplinary teams.

Recruit specialists as part of IHR implementation at the next recruitment to strengthen human resources. Explore and implement measures to organize and finance specialization and continuous professional education in public health, including epidemiology, laboratory, animal and environmental health.

Monitor the median number of years that public health personnel have been on staff rolls within the ministry and/or national institutes and post a list of current staff (if available), staff turnover and number of staff attending in-service training.
Evaluate existing field or applied epidemiology programmes in the regional context and identify the host country where national public health professionals can be sent for training.
Secure an acceptable location for field or applied epidemiology management.
Ensure availability of at least one trained epidemiologist per 500 000 population.
Expand epidemiology training programmes into three levels of training programmes with career tracks established for graduates in additional jurisdictions.
Conduct a comprehensive multihazard health emergency risk assessment at the national level; include analysis of geographic areas and vulnerable subpopulations that may be at higher risk.
Develop or revise the plan for management and distribution of national stockpiles.
Implement rapid needs assessments, planning, management and distribution of stockpiles for public health events.
Document and disseminate findings on risk assessment and experience, addressing suspected or confirmed health threats.
Review current health sector multihazard emergency response plans and other response plans for specific hazards.
Conduct a national level simulation exercise to test the multi hazard response plan and adjust the plan based on the outcomes of the simulation or complete an after-action review of an actual event.
Implement training for emergency preparedness and response at subnational levels.

Develop a mechanism to ensure that dedicated resources are in place for testing and implementation of multisectoral, multihazard emergency response plans, contingency plans and SOPs at national and subnational levels including an emergency financing mechanism for emergency response.
Develop and implement SOPs for an ad-hoc emergency coordination mechanism during the events.
Develop a training plan for emergency response staff, including on the incident management system, and implement it at least at the national level.
Develop a mechanism to ensure that the national emergency response plan lays out the concept of operations for the entire emergency response system.
Develop and implement a tracking of decision-making procedure for the activatation of an EOC.
Identify and secure resources for implementing the EOC and related activities.
Conduct after-action reviews of events and share results of after-action reviews with stakeholders at subnational and national levels.
Develop and implement corrective action plans based on the exercises and after-action review findings at all levels.
Assess risk of significant biological (and chemical or radiological) incidents of concern to the country.

Determine sample collection, transport, storage, security and testing requirements among relevant sectors (i.e. public health, security authorities, agriculture) for biological threats and other incidents of concern (such as chemical, radiological).

Conduct joint training of public health, animal health and security authorities to orient, exercise and institutionalize knowledge of memorandum of understanding and other agreements related to all hazards.
Draft a national plan to send, receive, stockpile and deploy medical countermeasures.
Create deployment protocols, SOPs, technical guidelines and toolkits including communication materials, trainings and educational information to inform staff, the community and stakeholders.
Develop a rational and evidence-based strategy to prioritize resources and investments in medical countermeasures at the national level.
Identify points of contact at relevant multisectoral organizations.
Apply to the WHO EMT secretariat for mentorship and verification as an internationally classified EMT.
Achieve certification as a national or international EMT from WHO to support the national response.

Establish a dedicated risk communication unit or team to work on two-way communication with the public (including affected at-risk communities) using SOPs, priority tasks and dedicated responsibilities for communication and decisionmaking authority during a public health event at the national level.
Develop a mechanism for systematically collecting feedback from the community (such as through telephone hotline, social media forums, direct engagement).
Implement risk communication training across sectors and at subnational levels.
Evaluate the effectiveness of the coordination mechanism among all partners either through a real event or simulation exercise.
Develop a plan to engage key stakeholders at the national level.
Develop tools, procedures and methods for community engagement to obtain community feedback through surveys, hotlines, community dialogue or other means.
Identify competent authorities at each designated point of entry.
Implement the strategy with adequate resources to integrate designated points of entry into national surveillance systems.
Integrate designated points of entry into national surveillance systems for all-hazards with the involvement of all relevant sectors.
Train staff of all designated points of entry on guidance and SOPs for responding to at least events due to biological hazards.

Demonstrate capacity to apply ad hoc measures related to travellers at points of entry (such as medical referral, transport) for early detection, assessment and safe transfer of sick travellers to appropriate medical facilities at all designated points of entry.
Demonstrate capacity to apply recommended measures to disinfect, de-rat, disinsect, decontaminate or otherwise treat baggage, cargo, containers, conveyances, goods and postal parcels.
Share best practices for continuous improvement with all relevant stakeholders.

Identify and describe priority chemical events to inform planning, a process which can include conducting an inventory of potentially hazardous chemical sites and manufacturing facilities and a review of past chemical events.
Provide adequate resources to the national poison information service to operate on a 24/7 basis, and integrate the poisons information service into the public health surveillance system.
Monitor on a routine basis, the timeliness of the information sharing mechanism about events and potential risk.
Develop a mechanism to integrate the systems of public health surveillance and environmental monitoring that captures and assesses chemical exposures from different sources.
Disseminate these policies, plans and legislation for radiological event surveillance, alert and response to relevant stakeholders.
Procure or ensure access to stockpile to support radiation emergency preparedness and response, and develop a distribution plan for the event of an emergency.
Share information with relevant stakeholders regularly on the risk and threats that are potential for emergencies.
Develop and disseminate guidance to all sectors (such as animal health, food safety) on data sharing and interoperability.
Develop or review the national regulatory framework for appropriate use of antimicrobials in humans.
Complete trainings to support the management and distribution of stockpiles for public health events.

Establish a functional national EOC that includes dedicated plan and procedures, a secure physical space, an information and communication technology infrastructure for information management and support of emergency operations, and trained staff.
Develop or update the national health sector multihazard emergency response plan.
Assess the need for additional emergency preparedness measures, including policies, procedures, SOPs and financial mechanisms, required to strengthen emergency preparedness.
Review and develop emergency response plans for cross-border and multicountry events with regional counterparts and international partners.
Develop and implement the corrective action plan based on the exercises and after-action review findings at national and subnational levels.
Develop training materials for disease surveillance for national and subnational levels.
Implement periodic training programmes on emergency response procedures.
Establish external monitoring and oversight of biosafety and biosecurity practices.
Finalize SOPs for coordination of key health sector actors (such as surveillance, health facilities, emergency medical teams, mental health departments).
Establish an information security system for all sensitive documentation in facilities where dangerous pathogens and toxins are stored.
Develop pathogen control measures, including standards for containment, operational handling and failure reporting systems.
Conduct a laboratory and field validation of the use of point-of-care/rapid diagnostic tests for some priority diseases.
Develop a mechanism to ensure that staff at the national level have internationally recognized certification to ship potentially infectious specimens.
Review the effectiveness of emergency financing mechanism following any response to a public health emergencies and adjust procedures to ensure speed, transparency and accountability of all funds.
Develop a national multihazard, multisectoral emergency risk communication plan.

Establish a service agreement with a courier company (public or private) for specimen transportation from at least 50% of health facilities in the public sector throughout all major subdivisions of the country.
Establish a national external quality assessment programme for public health laboratories.
Collect population-based denominators, such as those recommended by WHO GLASS.
Develop a mechanism to conduct baseline surveys on knowledge, attitudes and practices on priority health threats and on health seeking practices.

Put in place agreements with designated quality assured laboratories (national or laboratories in other countries) for timely analysis of biological and environmental samples with suspected chemical exposure.
Establish SOPs for communicating and coordinating with WHO, including trigger and process for notification and reporting.
Develop a national IPC policy and plan for animal health.
Identify potential barriers and/or challenges to implementing the national action plan and approaches to overcome these barriers.

Develop a mechanism for systematic exchange of information among different functions of an emergency response (such as surveillance, laboratory, patient care, infection prevention and control, logistics, risk communication, human resources, planning, budget and finance).
Develop triggers for sharing information on biological threats or other incidents of concern (such as chemical, radiological) with relevant multisectoral agencies.
Refer to the recommendations and requirements for IPC guidelines, and train adequate healthcare workers on issued guidelines.
Assess the capacity and essential functioning of target human and animal health laboratories to meet diagnostic and confirmatory requirements for priority diseases.

Establish SOPs, protocols and databases for surveillance data, a system for reporting to ministries of health and agriculture, and a mechanism to analyse data and report back to facilities and to WHO.
Assess vaccine delivery assessment in hard-to-reach areas, targeted based on existing coverage/registry/surveillance data, and use results to improve vaccine delivery to these areas.
Secure an agreement with another country to host participants and establish funding mechanisms to support the training.
Develop a response document to observe appropriate authorizations, clearances, ethical norms and permissions during vaccine delivery.
Establish procedures for procurement, storage and transportation of vaccines during public health emergencies.
Develop communication channels, such as website updates or newsletters, to apprise relevant sectors and partners on developments in the relation to IHR implementation.
Develop national guidance documents for vaccine stockpile and deployment, and obtain approval from ministry of health (and ministry of agriculture, where applicable).

Conduct an evaluation of surveillance data to ensure that the case-based surveillance system is sufficiently sensitive to detect cases (such as measles immunoglobulin M negative febrile rash incidence rate ≥2 per 100 000 population) at the district/province/state levels.
Promote immunizations and sensitize communities through routine messaging via traditional/social media, and engaging civil society organizations and religious leaders.

Expand current public health and field epidemiology training programmes to include: refresher courses; an induction programme for field epidemiologists; regular in-service programmes and continuous professional development programmes for animal health staff; and a sustainable methodology and process to provide continuous and regular education for field epidemiology staff from both human and animal health sectors.
Identify focal points for community engagement at the national and subnational levels.
Develop guidelines, SOPs, training materials and toolkits on pre- and postservice guidance for immunizations; and train healthcare workers.

Establish a database of human resources in all relevant sectors and levels of the public health system that can provide multidisciplinary health personnel during public health emergencies with SOPs for updating and maintaining it.
Identify and train community outreach groups, including volunteers.

Develop and disseminate guidance and tools to increase routine immunization services, with a focus on first-dose measles coverage and conduct activities to ensure 50–69% first-dose measles coverage of the country’s 12-month-old population with at least one dose of MCV.
Conduct a Total Diet Study or similar study and implement outcomes to complement the existing national monitoring and surveillance strategy.
Sustain a mechanism to ensure response capacity at national, subnational and local levels.
Test for foodborne diseases and/or contamination for the cases or events detected through indicator- or event-based disease surveillance to assign aetiology.
Assess capacities for chemical event surveillance, alert and response at all levels (national, subnational).
Develop guidelines for management of radiological waste including that from the hospitals and medical services.
Conduct review of appropriate medical services including diagnostic facilities for the prompt assessment and care of sick travellers as per Annex 1B, 1(a), and identify gaps and corrective actions.

Finalize a written protocol or memorandum of understanding that formalizes and institutionalizes interactions between relevant multisectoral agencies (public health, animal health and security authorities).
Share the plans with national, subnational and local IPC committees and incorporate guidance from them.
Recommend and implement the phasing out of antimicrobials used as animal growth promotion.

Regularly monitor or evaluate the capacity for preparedness and response measures at points of entry either during real events or through simulation exercises and update the contingency plan and response mechanism.
Implement a national regulatory framework for appropriate use of affordable, quality assured antimicrobials in humans and animals.
Develop a strategy for continuous improvement and regularly monitor and evaluate routine capacities at points of entry.
Link surveillance activities with the surveillance technical area benchmarks.
Review and update the operational plan/mechanism based on the results of monitoring and evaluation.
Publish these policies/strategies and plan.
Integrate all designated points of entry into the national emergency preparedness and response plan.
Allocate resources including funds to all designated points of entry for implementation of the plan during the events.
Develop adequate laboratory capacity and standards within relevant sectors to detect zoonotic diseases.
Establish terms of reference and job descriptions for intermediate level (provincial, district) rapid response teams and public health officer in-charge of outbreak preparedness and response.
Document and disseminate annual reports of the multisectoral workforce strategic plan which is completed and has been implemented consistently.

Identify a sustainable funding mechanism for field or applied epidemiology; consider basic level field or applied epidemiology with a plan for expansion into intermediate and advanced levels of field or applied epidemiology, as determined by country needs.

Establish a national case for investment in human resources for health as a vital component of the Sustainable Development Goals, Universal Health Coverage and universal access to healthcare (Global Strategy on HRH 2030 Obj3.59).
Document and disseminate the public health workforce/human resource strategy.
Operationalize a mechanism for monitoring data quality and analysis at national and intermediate levels.
Develop standards, content and format of an epidemiological bulletin for national, intermediate and local levels.
Develop a tool and standards for data quality assessment.
Document the incidence of patient and healthcare worker infections, including M. tuberculosis, and the effectiveness of measures to reduce their occurrence.
Designate laboratories and secure laboratory reagents to conduct detection and reporting of some priority AMR pathogens.
Train 80% of national- and intermediate-level surveillance staff on application/software for surveillance.
Establish a link of the electronic system under development to the existing health information management system.
Train early responders in the appropriate use and management of countermeasures.
Monitor implementation of cross-border surveillance and demonstrate that information-sharing protocol is effective.
Conduct regular training on SOPs, guidelines, procedures and best practices at all levels, including at the local/health facility level, for surveillance staff.

Allocate the budget, either domestic or external funds, to the relevant sectors and their respective ministries to support the implementation of IHR capacities for biological hazards at the national level. Develop the resource mobilization strategy and advocacy tools for the financing and identify key stakeholders. Develop a mechanism to lobby for domestic resources (both government and private sectors).
Conduct regular training for surveillance staff on SOPs, guidelines, procedures and best practices at national and intermediate levels.

Conduct a prioritization exercise to assign priorities to those risk scenarios described in the strategic health emergency risk assessments, including those that pose the greatest threats to public health.
Conduct a risk assessment for radiation hazards.
Develop protocols, SOPs, technical guidelines and toolkits for sending and receiving health personnel, and for sharing information as appropriate.
Secure sustainable funding for epidemiology training programmes and career tracks and pursue accreditation.
Develop an orientation package to implement the legislation, laws, regulations, policy and administrative requirements.
Implement measures for the management and distribution of stockpiles at the national level.
Approve and enact legislation and regulations on import, marketing authorization, production and use of antimicrobials.
Develop SOPs for medical services (identification of diagnostic facilities to collaborate with care of sick travellers and referral).
Map existing relevant legislation and begin the review process for coherence.
Establish a waste management site with the required capacity for monitoring it.
Develop a training plan for rapid logistics needs asessments, and planning, management and distribution of stockpiles for public health events.
Develop a strategy and action plan to increase capacities.
Develop SOPs defining the process and communication mechanisms for assessing and responding to suspected international events.
Develop course curriculum, maintain scientific excellence in training, monitoring and evaluating trainees, and consult on epidemiological methods.
Develop and implement a training programme for national EOC staff including management, communications, finance and logistics.

Develop guidelines and SOPs for the detection of foodborne events and implement indicator-/event-based disease surveillance (refer to indicator-/ event-based disease surveillance columns for respective benchmarks).
Develop and implement strategies for monitoring national AMR and drug-resistant TB.
Review national level resources (critical stock levels for priority risks) on an annual basis or when needed.
Develop a radiation monitoring mechanism with required SOPs and guidelines, and establish a mechanism to share information among the relevant stakeholders.
Monitor “prescription only” sales of key antibiotics.
Train or recruit human resources for the implementation of IHR capacities for all relevant sectors at the national level.
Establish an inventory system that monitors and transmits vaccine supply and requirements at all needed levels.
Establish a mechanism to ensure regular collaboration among staff responsible for surveillance, risk assessment and risk communication.
Integrate all designated points of entry into the national emergency preparedness and response plan with the involvement of relevant sectors and services.
Develop operational plans for the management of at least two priority zoonotic diseases of greatest national public health concern.
Implement the multi hazard response plan at the national level.
Ensure availability of at least one trained epidemiologist per 200 000 population.
Develop plans to perform catch-up campaigns or supplemental immunization activities, based on epidemiologic and coverage data.
Develop and disseminate training on community engagement at the national and subnational levels.
Conduct advocacy to implement the strategy to relevant stakeholders, including ministries of health, finance, planning and administration/civil service.
Disseminate case definitions and process of detection, assessment, and reporting of cases (user manual or guidelines) at national and intermediate levels.
Establish a cold chain for vaccine delivery to at least 40% of districts or 40% of the target population.
Conduct activities to achieve 70–89% first-dose measles coverage of the country’s 12-month-old population with at least one dose of MCV.
Develop capacity to conduct periodic assessment of data quality at the national level.
Develop and implement equipment operation and maintenance plans at laboratories storing pathogens of security concern.
Establish One Health AMR training and mentorship programmes for national and country laboratories.
Develop or adopt the risk assessment protocol of acute foodborne events (chemical and microbiological).

Train staff and develop protocols to share data with regional or international actors (such as sharing influenza data in Global Influenza Surveillance and Response System and/or FluNET (a global web-based tool for influenza virological surveillance))
Establish monitoring and evaluation tools to evaluate the implementation of risk communication activities during public health emergencies.
Conduct recruitment and selection of participants for field or applied epidemiology training in host country.
Develop and conduct a table-top exercise, if countermeasures (which includes sending and receiving medical countermeasures) have not been deployed in the previous year.

Implement national biosafety and biosecurity regulations and guidelines with all relevant sectors (such as human, animal, environmental health, defence ministry and stakeholders) with standardized classification and accreditation standards that cover pathogen control and personnel reliability programme requirements.
Establish SOPs for communication among relevant sectors, including thresholds for reporting and response.
Evaluate and validate the AEFI reporting system.
Establish a mechanism to contribute to regional or international surveillance networks.
Develop and implement point-of-care diagnostic testing strategies for priority diseases.

Establish an informal or formal communications process to share information, based on identified triggers, related to biological threats or other incidents of concern (such as chemical, radiological) among relevant multisectoral agencies (such as public health, animal health and security authorities).

Develop plan, based on assessment, to target human and animal health laboratories for capacity building and essential functioning to meet diagnostic and confirmatory requirements for priority diseases, ensuring that proficiency is demonstrable for bacteriology, serology, polymerase chain reaction and others.
Identify legislative/policy champion(s) or broker(s) who can advocate for the law or policy to reach a successful end state.

Develop a national surveillance protocol including: surveillance targets, laboratory standards, priority specimens, pathogens and drug– bug combinations, defined datasets, metrics, data production, analysis and reporting, quality management, monitoring and evaluation).
Identify, train and roster a pool of surge staff for emergency response coordination.
Monitor IPC and WASH implementation in selected healthcare facilities using IPCAF, hand hygiene self-assessment framework, hand hygiene compliance observation tools WASH FIT tool.
Assess existing capacities and needs within government ministries and key partner agencies, and develop training plans for priority skills identified for carrying out effective risk communication.
Identify and document barriers to registering, as well as receiving and deploying national/international health personnel and teams, including safety and liability guidance for personnel deployment.
Establish a mechanism to ensure transportation of specimens from 50% of all health facilities to national laboratories.

Map current national level resources to support the emergency response of the health sector at the national level, including human resources, finances, infrastructure, logistics and supplies (such as health facilities, emergency operation centres, transport, vehicles, cold chain capacity, telecommunications, warehousing, supply routes).
Develop a national strategic framework to prioritize resources and investments in immunization.
Develop and implement a training plan for strengthening emergency preparedness measures and the multi hazard response plan at the national level.

Designate field supervisors and mentors for field or applied epidemiology and prepare guidelines for mentorship designated to monitor trainee activity, development of projects, barriers to training, among others.
Track the training and rostering of field or applied epidemiology participants and graduates in host country.
Train staff on joint risk assessment and application of triggers, and sharing of information among all sectors relevant to hazards.
Develop training curriculum using country-specific content (such as regulations/authorities, agency roles/responsibilities and case studies).
Develop and initiate training programmes for data collection and reporting of AMR at national and regional levels.
Develop SOPs and training for the organization, transportation and distribution of personal protective equipment, medications and supplies to health personnel.
Train relevant staff on these SOPs, guidelines and information sharing.
Develop and implement indicator based surveillance or event-based surveillance (refer to respective column for their benchmarks).
Develop an action plan to replace dangerous pathogen cultures with safer investigation methods.
Provide preposition outbreak investigation kits (sample collection and transportation kits) in at least 50% of health facilities.
Train frontline healthcare staff on effective risk communication.
Establish domestic external quality assessment programmes for all priority tests or cover them with international external quality assessment schemes.
Establish a functional national body to assess and recommend an evidence-based national vaccine policy.
Develop training and exercises for hazard-specific response and management plans with sectors, stakeholders and other agencies.
Develop guidelines and tools for safety and waste management and disseminate to all health facilities.
Develop a standardized system of monitoring and reporting of adverse events following immunization.
Develop an information-sharing protocol and mechanism that will apply to all relevant stakeholders involved in foodborne disease surveillance and food contamination monitoring.
Train staff on medical services SOPs and ensure the provision of adequate resources including space, equipment and premises as per Annex 1B, 1(a), 1(b).
Develop and disseminate a training package on these guidelines and SOPs.
Develop case management guidelines to manage cases of radiation emergencies (either as a stand-alone guideline or as part of the case management guidelines for all hazards (refer to Benchmark 14.3)).
Develop and disseminate training packages on the operational plan, associated guidelines and SOPs.
Complete the review of relevant legislation and enact amendments to make legislation coherent.
Develop and implement legislation on “prescription only” sales of key antibiotics.

Develop action plans for multisectoral/multidisciplinary coordination and communication mechanisms in a variety of settings including during times of high risk, deliberate events and mass gathering events.
Develop guidelines and SOPs for surveillance, alert and response to chemical events and emergencies including for laboratories, and develop training packages on these guidelines and SOPs.
Designate functional AMR surveillance sites.
Develop standardized forms and templates for data/information management, reporting, briefing and record-keeping.
Establish alumni association for epidemiology graduates (all levels).
Secure capacity required for emergency preparedness measures for specific hazards or risk scenarios, including contingency planning, additional training and equipment.
Establish indicator-based surveillance: Develop guidelines and SOPs for indicator-based surveillance.
Initiate AMR surveillance at pilot or representative regional and referral hospitals.
Begin developing incident and emergency response programmes in facilities storing dangerous pathogens.
Procure logistics for robust radiation monitoring systems.
Ensure availability of at least one trained epidemiologist per two million population.
Establish indicator-based disease surveillance: Develop guidelines and SOPs for priority foodborne diseases.
Establish capacities at designated points of entry of appropriate medical services as per IHR Annex 1B, 1(a).
Develop standardized plans for treatment centres for triage, IPC and treatment during emergency incidents.
Develop a database of subject matter experts for consultation on priority hazards.
Provide annual reports to the World Health Assembly on IHR capacity development.
Develop training and SOPs for mentors and supervisors.
Develop capacities for diagnosis and treatment of chemical poisonings and establish a poison information service that operates at least during office hours.
Designate a focal point or unit within the animal and human health sectors and other relevant sectors and formalize a coordination mechanism for priority zoonotic diseases/pathogens.
Operationalize a standardized system of monitoring and reporting of adverse events following immunization (AEFIs) at all health facilities.
Develop a national laboratory policy that identifies expected capacities at each level of the national laboratory system.
Identify health facilities that can manage patients in the event of a radiation emergency.
Establish a communication network for health personnel during emergencies.
Develop a strategy to establish all the routine capacities prescribed in the IHR Annex 1B, 1.
Assess existing laboratory capacities for the analysis of human and environmental samples to inform the assessment and management investigation of chemical events and poisonings.
Develop a hands-on-training curriculum for all laboratory staff that includes task-based training, refresher training and mentoring in their appropriate technical and administrative areas.
Designate or secure access to laboratory capacity to monitor, identify and assess exposure.
Develop mechanisms and SOPs for implementing domestic and international surge capacity as part of the multihazard response plan.
Establish indicator-based surveillance: Establish a designated unit at all levels, with operational plan and procedures.
Identify critical pieces of information to inform emergency response, such as epidemic intelligence, and develop systems to capture and manage this information.
Establish indicator-based disease surveillance: Establish a designated unit at all levels with operational plan and procedures.
Disseminate field or applied epidemiology training materials, protocols, SOPs and toolkits.
Train relevant healthcare workers on these protocols and guidelines.
Develop tools for emergency health disaster education of the public for community acceptance of deployed health personnel.
Develop a mechanism for systematic information exchange between competent radiological authorities and human health surveillance units about radiological events and potential risks.
Establish accreditation mechanisms for health training institutes.
Establish a performance-monitoring framework including indicators, criteria and timelines for emergency response.
Develop plans to link laboratory and surveillance information to the emergency response communications structure.

Establish indicator-based disease surveillance: Establish and disseminate case definitions, process of detection, assessment and reporting of cases (user manual or guidelines) to national and subnational levels.
Develop a strategy to integrate designated points of entry into national surveillance systems.
Establish indicator-based surveillance: Include country priority diseases in indicator-based surveillance.
Conduct a hands-on training or refresher training session for public health laboratory staff on techniques to diagnose the country’s priority diseases.
Develop and disseminate testing SOPs and quality control SOPs for all core tests for priority diseases; and establish supply and procurement chains.
Establish event-based disease surveillance: Develop guidelines and SOPS.
Draft a national plan to send and receive health personnel.
Conduct recruitment and selection of candidates for training including consideration for participation of veterinarians in the epidemiology training programme.

Establish indicator-based surveillance: Disseminate case definitions and ensure that process of detection,assessment and reporting of cases (user manual or guidelines) are in place at national and subnational levels.
Track field or applied epidemiology capacity in the country including graduates and positions after training.
Establish event-based surveillance: Develop guidelines and standard operating procedures for eventbased surveillance.
Apply to WHO EMT secretariat for assistance in developing national EMTs.
Train relevant laboratory staff on techniques used for core testing and document quality control results.
Establish event-based disease surveillance: Establish a designated unit at all needed levels with operational plan and procedures.
Establish a partnership with other countries in the region to share epidemiology training programme graduates during emergency events.
Establish event-based surveillance: Establish a designated unit at all needed levels, with operational plan and procedures.

Establish event-based disease surveillance: Develop and put in place case definitions, process of detection, assessment and reporting of events (clusters or outbreaks) for country priority diseases, and dissemination to national and subnational levels.
Ensure availability of at least one trained epidemiologist per one million population.

Establish event-based disease surveillance: Establish a process to capture events from community and other sources (such as media, social media, private sector), and make the data available at all needed levels.

Establish event-based surveillance: Develop and put in place case definitions and the process of detection, assessment and reporting of the event (clusters or outbreaks) for country priority diseases and disseminate to national and subnational levels.

Establish event-based surveillance: Establish a process to identify potential events from communitybased reporting (people identified from the community, verification teams at facilities identified, SOP and flow of information available) and make the data available at all needed levels.
Establish event-based surveillance: Establish systems to identify potential events from various other sources (such as media, social media, private sector).
